comments.author: michiel@mozillafoundation.org
comments.text:
User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.1; en-US) AppleWebKit/534.13 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/9.0.597.98 Safari/534.13
Build Identifier: 3.x

Currently Thunderbird (not rarely unwantedly) applies certain OpenType features by default, but there is no way to see which in the Tools -> Options -> Display -> Formatting -> Fonts -> [Advanced] section.

This seems to make it impossible for people to pick which features to apply, and which not to apply (even common features that in typesetting should be turned on, like ligatures, may in fact be highly unwanted in digital correspondence that will never be printed).

Additionally, there is no OpenType features selector in the context menu when typing a selecting a stretch of text that should have certain features selectively applied.

These two missing features makes the decision to turn on OpenType features by default dubious - I know I personally want them turned off most of the time because they make my emails harder to read, and want them turned on for specific bits of text where they're crucial (typesetting discussions), but can't.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start a new email and write some text with 'fi', 'ffi', 'ti', and other common ligatures.
Actual Results:  
Thunderbird automatically applies whatever the OpenType "liga" feature says it should do, without a way for the user to tell it that it shouldn't


This is a feature request to increase Thunderbird's usability. Applying or not applying certain OpenType features without a way for users to regulate which to apply when, means Thunderbird makes a decision on typesetting that it should not be allowed to make without consulting the user.

Are such settings available in Firefox ?
comments.author: ludovic@hirlimann.net
comments.text: Are such settings available in Firefox ?
comments.creator: ludovic@hirlimann.net
michiel@mozillafoundation.org
comments.raw_text:
I didn't look for one, but Firefox is a program for viewing content on webpages, with explicit CSS per webpage. If you see ligatures, it's a good bet the author of the webpage intended for you to see ligatures. The Gecko engine will simply render what it is instructed to render on a page-by-page basis.

Thunderbird, on the other hand, has not websites to load. Somewhere the Thunderbird program instucts Gecko to use whatever CSS the designers of the program thought should be used, despite the fact that they should not have been the ones making that decision (a bit like making a text editor that only lets you write text in comic sans without a way to change the font). With the enrichment offered by CSS's feature selector, feature selector options should have been added.
